facts.text: Four persons appeal against sentences of death passed upon them for convictions in a double murder of brothers Rattan Singh and Bawa Singh.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by BosE J.-Four persons appeal against sentences of death passed upon them in companyvictions for a double murder, the victims being two brothers, Rattan Singh and Bawa Singh.

facts.text: Sessions Judge convicted all seven accused and sentenced them to transportation for life.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Sessions Judge companyvicted three others also but sentenced all, including the four appellants, to transportation for life.

facts.text: High Court acquitted three accused but sustained convictions of four appellants and enhanced sentences to death.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court acquitted three of the seven but sustained the companyvictions of the four appellants and enhanced their sentences in each case to death.

facts.text: All seven accused belong to the same village and same faction.

anchor.surface_text: All seven accused belong to the same village and belong to the same faction or party, as Mst. Punnan  P.W. 2  calls it.

facts.text: Appellants Dalip Singh and Battan Singh are brothers; Jarnail Singh (acquitted) is son of Battan Singh.

anchor.surface_text: Of the seven, the appellants Dalip Singh and Battan Singh are brothers. Jarnail Singh who was acquitted is a son of Battan Singh.

facts.text: Dalip Singh and Battan Singh assaulted Rattan and Bawa about twenty years before the occurrence and were convicted and served short terms.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants Dalip Singh and Battan Singh are said to have assaulted the two dead men Rattan and Bawa about twenty years before the occurrence.

facts.text: Dalip Singh and Battan Singh believed Rattan and Bawa furnished information to police about their dacoity, providing motive.

anchor.surface_text: Dalip Singh and Battan Singh are also said to be dacoits and it is said that they believed that the two dead men used to furnish information against them to the police.

facts.text: On 16th June 1951 around 2 p.m., Rattan Singh was taking food to a well near his house.

anchor.surface_text: On 16th June, 1951, Rattan Singh was taking some food out to a well a short distance from his house for himself and his son. This was about 2 p.m.

facts.text: Mst. Punnan (PW 2) and daughter Mst. Charni (PW 11) saw all seven accused assaulting Rattan Singh as he left house.

anchor.surface_text: Just as he left the house, his wife Mst. Punnan  P.W. 2  heard cries of alarm and on rushing out with her daughter Mst. Charni  P.W. 11  saw all seven accused assaulting her husband.

facts.text: Accused beat Rattan Singh till he fell to the ground.

anchor.surface_text: They beat him up till he fell to the ground.

facts.text: Accused then rushed to Rattan Singh's Haveli, assaulted Bawa Singh on cot, dragged him out, beat more.

anchor.surface_text: As soon as Rattan Singh fell down, they left him and rushed to his  Rattan Singhs  Haveli where the other brother Bawa Singh was lying on a company, shouting that they would also make short work of him.

facts.text: Accused returned to Rattan Singh and gave more blows, then ran away.

anchor.surface_text: After this they returned to where Rattan Singh was still lying on the ground and gave him some more blows. Then they ran away.

facts.text: Bawa Singh died very shortly after assault; Rattan Singh survived a little longer but died not long after.

anchor.surface_text: Bawa Singh died very shortly after the assault. The other brother survived a little longer but he also died number long after.

facts.text: Weapons: Dalip and Sadhu with barchhas (spears), Battan and two acquitted with lathis, Kundan with takwa (hatchet), Kehar with khunda.

anchor.surface_text: According to Mst. Punnan  P.W. 2  the accused were armed as follows The appellants Dalip Singh and Sadhu Singh with barchhas the appellant Battan Singh and two of the accused who have been acquitted with lathis

facts.text: Rattan Singh had 19 injuries, 2 fatal on head by blunt weapons, 6 grievous others on non-vital parts.

anchor.surface_text: The medical evidence discloses that Rattan Singh had nineteen injuries on his person. Of these, only two, on the head, would have been fatal in themselves. The rest were on number-vital parts

facts.text: Death of Rattan due to shock from multiple injuries and brain haemorrhage from injury No.14.

anchor.surface_text: The doctor says death was caused by shook produced by the multiple injuries aided by haemorrhage in the brain due to injury No. 14.

facts.text: Bawa Singh had 16 injuries, 2 on vital parts (head and spleen rupture), 11 grievous.

anchor.surface_text: The other brother Bawa had sixteen injuries but except for two the rest were on number-vital parts. One of the two was on the head and the other ruptured the spleen.

facts.text: Dalip Singh arrested 17th June 1951, other three appellants on 18th, all wearing blood-stained clothes.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant Dalip Singh was arrested on the 17th June and the other three on the 18th. Each was wearing blood-stained clothes.

facts.text: Weapons recovered on 30th June 1951, some blood-stained, pointed by Jarnail and Sadhu.

anchor.surface_text: The learned High Court Judges did number attach any importance to the recovery of the weapons because for one thing they were number recovered till the 30th, that is to say, number until fourteen days after the murders

facts.text: Sessions Judge convicted all seven under section 302/149 IPC based on eyewitnesses PW2 and PW11.

anchor.surface_text: But he was impressed with the evidence of the two eyewitnesses Mst. Punnan  P.W. 2  and Mst. Charni W. 11  and believing them companyvicted each of the seven accused under section 302 read with section 149

facts.text: High Court relied on blood-stained clothes for corroboration of four appellants.

anchor.surface_text: They found companyroboration in the case of the four appellants because of the blood-stained clothes and numbere in the case of the others.

facts.text: FIR made by Mst. Punnan at 8:30 p.m. on 16th June 1951, naming all seven accused, 6.5 hours after, 12 miles from station.

anchor.surface_text: The first information report was made by Mst. Pullnan  P.W. 2  herself. It was made at 8-30 p.m. within 6- 1/2 hours of the occurrence at a place 12 miles from the police station.

facts.text: Supreme Court upholds convictions of four appellants under 302/149 IPC, acquittals of three stand.

anchor.surface_text: On that finding the companyviction under section 302 read with section 149 can be sustained. We accordingly uphold these companyvictions. The acquittals in the other the cases will of companyrse stand

facts.text: Supreme Court sets aside death sentences, restores transportation for life as per Sessions Judge.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to hold that the discretion was improperly exercised by the learned Sessions Judge.

facts.text: High Court found at least not less than five persons took part.

anchor.surface_text: that certainly number less than five persons took part in the beating of the two deceased

issues.text: Whether the conviction of the four appellants under section 302 read with section 149 IPC can be sustained given the High Court's acquittal of three accused and uncertain finding on the presence of at least five persons sharing common object

anchor.surface_text: Now it is clear from the above that it is impossible to ascribe any particular injury to any particular person. Therefore it is impossible to convict any one of the accused of murder simpliciter under section 302, nor do the learned Judges attempt to do that. They convict under section 302 read with section 149.

issues.text: Whether the testimony of the two eyewitnesses (Mst. Punnan and Mst. Charni), being women and relatives, requires corroboration

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to agree with the learned Judges of the High Court that the testimony of the two eyewitnesses requires corroboration. If the foundation for such an observation is based on the fact that the witnesses are women and that the fate of seven men hangs on their testimony, we know of no such rule.

issues.text: Whether section 34 IPC can be applied alternatively for conviction

anchor.surface_text: Nor is it possible in this case to have recourse to section 34 because the appellants have not been charged with that even in the alternative, and the common intention required by section 34 and the common object required by section 149 are far from being the same thing.

anchor.surface_text: If it is grounded on the reason that they are closely related to the deceased we are unable to concur. This is a fallacy common to many criminal cases and one which another Bench of this Court endeavoured to dispel in Rameshwar v. The State of Rajasthan

arguments.claim: In murder, death sentence ordinarily unless trial judge records reasons for lesser; appellate court interferes only if discretion improperly exercised
Enhancement from life to death by appellate court rare, only strongest reasons; here trial discretion proper due to vicarious liability under s149, unclear individual roles

holdings.text: Conviction under section 302 read with section 149 IPC for the four appellants is sustained based on reliable eyewitness testimony identifying all seven accused as participants sharing common object.

anchor.surface_text: On that finding the conviction under section 302 read with section 149 can be sustained. We accordingly uphold these convictions. The acquittals in the other the cases will of course stand

holdings.reasoning_summary: Court independently reviewed evidence, found eyewitnesses credible due to demeanour, consistency in FIR, weapons description matching post-mortem, blood-stained clothes and recoveries corroborating; rejected High Court's uncertainty as inconsistent with acquitting three while finding at least five.

holdings.text: Testimony of eyewitnesses does not require corroboration merely because they are women or relatives of deceased, or because fate of multiple accused depends on it; no such general rule of prudence exists.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to agree with the learned Judges of the High Court that the testimony of the two eyewitnesses requires corroboration. If the foundation for such an observation is based on the fact that the witnesses are women and that the fate of seven men hangs on their testimony, we know of no such rule.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cited Rameshwar v. State of Rajasthan; relationship often guarantees truth; each case on own facts; rejected High Court's basis as fallacy; assessed credibility on specifics like demeanour, cross-exam, FIR consistency.

holdings.text: Section 34 IPC cannot be applied as appellants not charged under it even alternatively, and common intention under s34 differs from common object under s149.

anchor.surface_text: Nor is it possible in this case to have recourse to section 34 because the appellants have not been charged with that even in the alternative, and the common intention required by section 34 and the common object required by section 149 are far from being the same thing.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Procedural bar due to absence of charge; conceptual distinction between intention and object prevents alternative recourse.

holdings.text: High Court improperly enhanced sentences from transportation for life to death; Sessions Judge's discretion to award lesser sentence was properly exercised.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to hold that the discretion was improperly exercised by the learned Sessions Judge.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Trial judge records reasons implicitly (uncertain attribution of fatal injuries under s149 vicarious liability); appellate enhancement rare, only for strongest reasons; High Court gave no reasons; proper to discriminate in group assault with unclear roles.

holdings.text: Evidence of dying declaration is unreliable and rejected.

anchor.surface_text: also that both courts have rejected the evidence about the dying declaration.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Accepted lower courts' rejection; not relied upon in final findings.

holdings.text: Section 149 IPC requires court to find with certainty at least five persons present sharing common object; cannot rest on uncertain or vacillating findings.

anchor.surface_text: Before section 149 can be called in aid, the court must find with certainty that there were at least five persons sharing the common object. A finding that three of them may or may not have been there betrays uncertainty on this vital point

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court's 'may or may not' for three acquitted created inconsistency with 'at least five'; precludes s149; but overcome by independent finding of all seven.

holdings.text: In murder cases, death sentence ordinarily imposed unless trial judge records reasons for lesser penalty; appellate court interferes only if discretion improperly exercised; enhancement from life to death very rare for strongest reasons.

anchor.surface_text: In a case of murder, the death sentence should ordinarily be imposed unless the trying Judge for reasons which should normally be recorded considers it proper to award the lesser penalty. But the discretion is his and if he gives reasons on which a judicial mind could properly found, an appellate court should not interfere.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Principle articulated for sentencing discretion in murder, especially group liability under s149 where individual roles unclear; trial judge's vicarious liability consideration proper.

precedents.citation: Rameshwar v. The State of Rajasthan 1

anchor.surface_text: Rameshwar v. The State of Rajasthan 1 .

precedents.case_name: Rameshwar v. The State of Rajasthan
precedents.cited_proposition: Fallacy that testimony of close relative of deceased requires corroboration as a general rule of prudence; each case to be judged on its own facts; relationship often guarantees truth

justification_sets.label: Judicial Discretion in Murder Sentencing support
Judicial Discretion in Murder Sentencing support

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly uphold these convictions. The acquittals in the other the cases will of course stand but the mere fact that these persons have, in our opinion, been wrongly acquitted cannot affect the conviction in the other cases. On the question of sentence, it would have been necessary for us to interfere in any event because a question of principle is involved. In a case of murder, the death sentence should ordinarily be imposed unless the trying Judge for reasons which should numbermally be recorded companysiders it proper to award the lesser penalty.

outcome.relief_summary: Convictions of the four appellants under section 302 read with section 149 IPC upheld; death sentences imposed by High Court set aside; sentences of transportation for life by Sessions Judge restored; acquittals of other three accused stand
directions: The acquittals in the other the cases will of course stand

anchor.surface_text: On that finding the conviction under section 302 read with section 149 can be sustained. We accordingly uphold these convictions. The acquittals in the other the cases will of course stand

We accordingly uphold these convictions. The acquittals in the other the cases will of course stand but the mere fact that these persons have, in our opinion, been wrongly acquitted cannot affect the conviction in the other cases. On the question of sentence, it would have been necessary for us to interfere in any event because a question of principle is involved. In a case of murder, the death sentence should ordinarily be imposed unless the trying Judge for reasons which should numbermally be recorded companysiders it proper to award the lesser penalty.

We are unable to agree with the learned Judges of the High Court that the testimony of the two eyewitnesses requires corroboration. If the foundation for such an observation is based on the fact that the witnesses are women and that the fate of seven men hangs on their testimony, we know of no such rule.

We accordingly uphold these convictions. The acquittals in the other the cases will of course stand but the mere fact that these persons have, in our opinion, been wrongly acquitted cannot affect the conviction in the other cases. On the question of sentence, it would have been necessary for us to interfere in any event because a question of principle is involved. In a case of murder, the death sentence should ordinarily be imposed unless the trying Judge for reasons which should numbermally be recorded companysiders it proper to award the lesser penalty.
